stream_context.summary: Kaze debugs a persistent crash in the Course 13 overworld, eventually tracing it to a faulty coin formation actor. He then pivots to designing and creating initial assets for a new retro level inspired by Super Mario Land 1's plane stage, deciding on a fixed-camera, on-rails shooter gameplay style.

development_findings.summary: Kaze hypothesizes that if he were sent back to 1995, his first act would be to optimize the original SM64 render code, which he claims would achieve a stable 30 FPS and make adding Luigi a trivial task.
development_findings.quote: The first thing I do is fix the graph render code. Make it all fit into one block of cache. And now the entire game runs at 30 FPS. And we can add Luigi to the game. And it's going to be two days of work.

development_findings.summary: Kaze debugs a persistent crash by methodically disabling level actors, eventually tracing the source to a specific coin formation. Fixing it revealed he had inadvertently undone previous UV mapping work.
development_findings.quote: Aha! This was the cause for the crash.

development_findings.summary: The project has a strict design rule that any 'retro' themed levels must be based on games that were released before Super Mario 64.
development_findings.quote: That's the rule. We want it to fit in the time.

development_findings.summary: The Super Mario Land 1 level is being designed as a 60 FPS on-rails shooter with a fixed camera perspective, a creative solution to adapt the 2D gameplay into 3D.
development_findings.quote: The camera will be permanently stuck like this. Then you're allowed to move in screen space, but you're not allowed to move the location of the camera.

development_findings.summary: The decision to make the Super Mario Land 1 level an on-rails shooter was heavily influenced by the practical challenge of creating front-facing sprites for a side-scrolling level. The level will be black and white to honor the original's aesthetic.
development_findings.quote: I don't want to make front sprites for everything... Now we're definitely doing the whole thing in black and white. That's essential to the aesthetic.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has permanently swapped two of the game's core drawing layers, a fundamental engine change that requires manual correction in every level file.
development_findings.quote: I'm swapping layer 5 and layer 6, because I swapped them on my repo. These have to be swapped. In every level.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is starting to model a 3D version of the plane from Super Mario Land 1, working from the original 16x16 sprite and aiming for a low-poly result suitable for the N64.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is balancing new fatherhood with the need to earn more money, leading him to increase his streaming schedule as he finds it to be an efficient work method.
context_findings.quote: I got three whole months of it long for having a child. But also, I need to work more because I want to make more money. So that's why I'm gonna just stream like basically every day now. Because I'm very efficient working on stream.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's parents are currently visiting him in Germany for 10 days, which involves personal obligations like yard work, and they gifted him a large number of Yoshi plushies.
context_findings.quote: My parents are visiting us in Germany right now, and it's quite a bit of work... they brought like 15 Yoshis. I have so many Yoshi plushies now.

context_findings.summary: Kaze jokingly entertains the idea of using the game's idle thread to mine cryptocurrency as a way for players to 'give back'.
context_findings.quote: Dude, that actually, generally, we could do that. We could mine Bitcoin in the idle thread while you're playing the game.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a pragmatic philosophy of exclusively supporting one emulator (Project64) to avoid the multiplied workload of working around bugs in multiple, flawed emulators.
context_findings.quote: If I wanted to support a second emulator, I would have to also work around all the bugs in that emulator. So for me, I just have to pick one emulator and run with it.

biobak.summary: Biobak suggests creating a retro level based on Wario Land (Super Mario Land 3), but Kaze is insistent on using Super Mario Land 1, partly for personal nostalgia.
biobak.quote: Super Mario Land 3, Mario Land type Retro Level. Didn't that come out after Mario 64? Oh, it was 1994. I guess that works too. But I really want Mario Land 1.

zeina.summary: Zeina is mentioned in a personal capacity as Kaze's wife during a 'meme reveal', but her contributions as an animator are not discussed in this stream.

key_stories.title: The Coin Formation Crash Hunt
key_stories.summary: Kaze faced a show-stopping crash in a level. Through a systematic process of disabling game elements, he traced the problem not to collisions but to a single coin formation actor. Fixing the crash allowed him to proceed, but also highlighted the cascading nature of bugs and fixes in development.
key_stories.challenge: A persistent and unidentified game crash in 'Course 13' was blocking all progress on the level.
key_stories.process: Kaze first suspected collision geometry was the problem. When that failed, he began a methodical process of elimination, disabling groups of actors in the level until the crash ceased, ultimately isolating the single faulty object.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully identified a specific coin formation actor as the source of the crash and removed it, allowing development to continue. However, this process also revealed he had accidentally undone some previous UV mapping work.
key_stories.key_quote: How is it crashing still? Yes. It's one of the actors that's crashing.

key_stories.title: From 2D Classic to 3D On-Rails Shooter
key_stories.summary: To represent Super Mario Land 1, Kaze had to devise a concept that was engaging in 3D. After rejecting ideas that were too asset-intensive, he designed a fixed-camera, on-rails shooter based on the plane stage, creating a new gameplay experience while preserving the original's black-and-white aesthetic.
key_stories.challenge: The team needed to create a retro level based on Super Mario Land 1, but had to find a way to make it compelling in 3D without simply recreating the original game poorly.
key_stories.process: Kaze debated ideas for the Super Mario Land 1 level. He rejected concepts like the submarine stage due to the high workload of creating new front-facing enemy sprites. He ultimately settled on the plane level, designing it as a forced-perspective shooter to create a novel experience while respecting the original's aesthetic.
key_stories.outcome: A clear design was established: the level will be a fixed-camera, on-rails shooter based on the original's plane stage. This concept was deemed both creatively interesting and technically feasible, allowing Kaze to begin asset creation.
key_stories.key_quote: Or do we actually just make it the side scroller? But then it's just the same game, but worse.

open_questions.topic: Details on planned 'Space Arcade' and 'Papercraft' levels
open_questions.context: Kaze mentions that the 'Space Arcade' and 'Papercraft' levels are the last two planned for the game, but provides no further details.
questions: What are the core gameplay concepts behind the 'Space Arcade' and 'Papercraft' levels?
What games or media inspired their design?
How do these final two levels fit into the game's overall progression and narrative?

open_questions.context: A chatter mentions that calling Kaze's physics changes 'Raycast physics' doesn't do them justice. Kaze agrees but doesn't elaborate on the system's true power or scope.
questions: What were the biggest limitations of the original SM64 physics that you needed to solve?
Beyond 'raycast physics,' how would you describe the fundamental changes you made to the engine?
Can you provide an example of a gameplay mechanic in the hack that would be impossible with the original physics engine?

open_questions.topic: Role of Contributor 'Lila' on Project Tooling
open_questions.context: Kaze refers to contributor 'Lila' multiple times for her work on an updater UI and repository settings, suggesting she plays a key role in the project's tooling and infrastructure.
questions: Who is Lila/Leela and what is her official role on the team?
How has her work on development tools and repository organization impacted the team's workflow?
Could you walk us through how her UI changes made the update process easier for developers?

open_questions.topic: Zeina's Creative Role and Collaborative Dynamic
open_questions.context: Zeina is identified as Kaze's wife and a team animator, but her specific creative contributions or influence on the project were not discussed.
questions: How do you and Zeina navigate the dynamic of being both spouses and creative collaborators on a major project?
Can you share an example of an animation Zeina created that solved a design problem or significantly improved the feel of a character or enemy?
What are her main animation tasks or challenges at this stage of development?

open_questions.topic: Reasoning for Scrapping the 'Yoshi's Story' Level
open_questions.context: Kaze states that a level based on 'Yoshi's Story' was planned at one point but was ultimately 'scratched because it's unfitting'.
questions: What was the original idea for the Yoshi's Story retro level?
What specifically about its aesthetic or gameplay was ultimately deemed 'unfitting' for Return to Yoshi's Island?
